review.title: Proposal for the creation of a research facility for the development of the SP machine
review.abstract: This is a proposal to create a research facility for the development of a high-parallel version of the "SP machine", based on the "SP theory of intelligence". We envisage that the new version of the SP machine will be an open-source software virtual machine, derived from the existing "SP computer model", and hosted on an existing high-performance computer. It will be a means for researchers everywhere to explore what can be done with the system and to create new versions of it. The SP system is a unique attempt to simplify and integrate observations and concepts across artificial intelligence, mainstream computing, mathematics, and human perception and cognition, with information compression as a unifying theme. Potential benefits and applications include helping to solve problems associated with big data; facilitating the development of autonomous robots; unsupervised learning, natural language processing, several kinds of reasoning, fuzzy pattern recognition at multiple levels of abstraction, computer vision, best-match and semantic forms of information retrieval, software engineering, medical diagnosis, simplification of computing systems, and the seamless integration of diverse kinds of knowledge and diverse aspects of intelligence. Additional motivations include the potential of the SP system to help solve problems in defence, security, and the detection and prevention of crime; potential in terms of economic, social, environmental, and academic criteria, and in terms of publicity; and the potential for international influence in research. The main elements of the proposed facility are described, including support for the development of "SP-neural", a neural version of the SP machine. The facility should be permanent in the sense that it should be available for the foreseeable future, and it should be designed to facilitate its use by researchers anywhere in the world.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: "There is nothing more practical than a good theory," says Kurt Lewin [7, p. 169]. This is a proposal to create a highly parallel version of the SP machine, which we will call "SPM," and a research facility for its further development, which we will call "SPF." It is envisaged that SPM will be created as an open source virtual software machine derived from the existing SP computer model (SP71) and hosted on an existing supercomputer. SPF will serve as a means for researchers everywhere to explore what can be done with the SP system and to develop new versions of it.

sections.heading: 1.1 The SP theory and the SP machine
sections.text: The basis of the proposed development is the SP Theory of Intelligence. This is a unique attempt to simplify and integrate observations and concepts relating to artificial intelligence, mathematics and human perception. Many potential benefits and applications result from this simplification and integration. The name "SP" is short for "Simplicity" and "Power," as it is indicated in the introduction to "Appendix." The SP Theory was not invented overnight.

sections.heading: 1.2 Presentation
sections.text: In the following we first describe some of the reasons for creating SPF (Section 2), then we describe the plant itself and how it can be used (Section 3). There is a cost estimate in Section 4 and concluding remarks in Section 5.

sections.heading: 2 Motivations
sections.text: In terms of the policies of the UK Government and UK Research Councils, SPM and SPF tick different boxes, and there are other reasons for the creation of SPF and the development of SPM. These motivations are described in the following paragraphs. 2From p. 9 in EPSRC E-Infrastructure Roadmap, August 2014, bit.ly / 1d8Eh3I.

sections.heading: 2.1 The power and potential of multiple alignment
sections.text: Perhaps the most characteristic feature of the SP system is the powerful concept of multiple alignment, since it has been adapted from bioinformatics (Appendix B). Broadly speaking, this concept provides a key to: • Simplification of concepts and systems. Various concepts in informatics and cognition can be assimilated to the relatively simple concept of multiple alignment ([19], [26, Sections 2 and 4]), and this concept can mean substantial simplification of computer systems ([19, Section 4.4.2], [26, Section 5]). • Versatility in intelligence. The SP system has strengths in unattended learning, natural language processing, pattern recognition, information gathering, different types of reasoning, planning, problem solving, information compression and more [19, 21]. • Adaptability in intelligence x.

sections.heading: 2.2 UK industrial strategy
sections.text: The development of the SPF would fit well with the objective of "supporting emerging technologies," one of the five main themes of the UK Industrial Strategy. [3] Specifically, the SPF fits well with the "Information Economy Strategy" 4 and its focus on "eight" major technologies that will drive the UK to future growth: [5] The SP system has considerable potential to contribute to the development of two of these "big technologies" - big data (which will be discussed in the next subsection) and robotics and autonomous systems (which will be discussed in section 2.4); the SP system is also relevant for development in a third area - energy - which will be briefly discussed in section 2.5); furthermore, the very broad scope of the SP system (section 2.1) and the provision of a facility for researchers around the world (section 3.4) through synergies of various types of "better science," "new types of science" and "interdisciplinary projects," in line with the "Strategic Vision of Government for UK Infrastructure" 6.

sections.heading: 2.3 Big data
sections.text: Here, we outline some significant challenges associated with big data and how the SP system can help overcome them.

sections.heading: 2.3.1 Challenges
sections.text: Some people tend to write or speak as if big data is an illegitimate boon and all the necessary technologies are available to use it. However, the book Smart Machines by John Kelly and Steve Hamm (both from IBM) [6] and also Frontiers in Massive Data Analysis by the US National Research Council [9] show that a large part of the potential value of big data cannot be realized at present due to significant unresolved problems in this area. Smart Machines also shows that significant problems related to big data cannot be solved by tinkering with existing computer concepts. sections.heading: 2.3.2 Potential solutions
sections.text: SPM and SPF are relevant to the problems just described because: the SP system was developed in the spirit of cognitive computing, drawing heavily on research on human perception and cognition and neuroscience; it offers radical solutions to problems arising from big data; and the existence of SPF would encourage and facilitate large-scale collaboration between researchers around the world. Big Data and SP Theory of Intelligence [24] paper describes how the SP system can help solve nine of the problems associated with big data, as outlined in Appendix C.13.1. Three of these problems and their potential solutions are highlighted here: • The problem of diversity in big data. There is an urgent need for calculation to tame the wide variety of formats and formats for the presentation of knowledge outlined in Appendix C.13.1.

sections.heading: 2.4 Robotics and autonomous systems
sections.text: As mentioned above, here too the system can make a contribution - perhaps in the form of robotics and autonomous systems (UK-RAS) - that it is not dependent on external intelligence, but in a way that is capable of unfolding.

sections.heading: 2.5 Energy
sections.text: The SP system can also indirectly contribute to another of the areas identified as one of the "eight major technologies" - energy - by increasing the efficiency of the operation of computers and data transmission, as described in sections 2.3 and 2.4 and described in more detail in [24, Sections VIII and IX] and also in [23, Section III].

sections.heading: 2.6 Other potential benefits and applications of the SP
sections.text: In addition to big data (Section 2.3), robotics and autonomous systems (Section 2.4) and energy (Section 2.5), there are several other potential benefits and applications of the SP system outlined in Appendix C. As mentioned there, several of these potential benefits and applications can be realized in relatively short periods of time with existing high-performance computers or even ordinary computers. Expert-reviewed papers on potential benefits and applications that have not yet been mentioned include [22] (application of SP theory to understanding natural vision and developing computer vision), [18] (application of the SP system to medical diagnosis) and [20] (the SP system as an intelligent database) and [26] (several other potential benefits and applications, including unattended learning, processing of natural language, pattern recognition, software engineering, information compression, the semantic web, bioinfomatics, data fusion, simplification of computer systems and seamless integration of structures and diverse types of knowledge).

sections.heading: 2.7 Defence, security, and the detection and prevention of
sections.text: crimeWith regard to "Security in a Changing World," part of the UK Science & Technology Facilities Council's (STFC) "Vision Types" [13, p. 13], several of the strengths of the SP system mentioned are relevant for defence, security and crime detection and prevention, including: • Big Data (Section 2.3) and data fusion [26, Section 6.10.5]. • Robotics and autonomous systems (Section 2.4). • Natural language processing [19, Chapter 5], [26, Section 6.2]. • Pattern recognition (see Appendix C.5 and [19, chapter 6]. • The SP system can function as an intelligent database [20]. • Different types of reasoning, including a single-level "deductive" reasoning "that leads to the solution of the problem.

sections.heading: 2.8 Contributing to the work of the planned Alan Turing
sections.text: Institute for Data Science and the proposed Cognitive Computing Research Centre "The Alan Turing Institute for Data Science will benefit over five years from a £42 million government investment that will reinforce the UK's ambition to be a world leader in the analysis and application of big data. It will also ensure that the UK is at the forefront of data science in a rapidly changing, globally competitive field, enabling world-class research in an environment that brings theory and practice together." 10The SP system and SPF have the potential to contribute to the work of the proposed Alan Turing Institute for Data Science, and also the planned Cognitive Computing Research Centre, 11 by facilitating both the analysis and application of big data (Section 2.3).

sections.heading: 2.10 International influence
sections.text: "Our priorities for maximising international influence are: greater influence for the UK in research, particularly in Europe; in the long term, the establishment of a major international research institution in the UK." [13, p. 21] Given the wide scope of the SP system, the international dimension of the SPF and its potential impact (Section 2.9), it has the potential to be "a major international research institution" and increase the international influence of the STFC or other host organisations.

sections.text: As mentioned in the introduction, SPF should allow the development of a highly parallel version of the SP machine, which is realized as virtual open source software and hosted on an existing high-performance computer. How things can develop is schematically shown in Figure 1.

sections.heading: 3.4 The facility should be available to researchers any-
sections.text: Where in the World As already mentioned, the broad scope of the SP system means that there are many more opportunities than any single research group could tackle on its own. Accordingly, we strive to create a facility for research groups and individual researchers anywhere in the world. It should not be limited to UK scientists: • This is consistent with what John Kelly and Steve Hamm say about the need for large-scale collaboration (quoted in Section 1.1) and also with the need to integrate e-infrastructures "internationally, across other national infrastructures, in order to provide end-to-end services in the global context of collaborative research" 24 and the need to facilitate... "research collaboration between industry and science." 25 • It also agrees with the principles that: - The EPSRC aims to "understand the entire UK e-infrastructure landscape, look at it holistically and consider it within an international context (emphasis added).

sections.heading: 3.5 The facility should be easy to access and easy to use
sections.text: In accordance with the main points in the previous section 2.9, it is important to minimize the obstacles to the use of the system for preliminary investigations, for teaching students, for individual research projects and for long-term research programs. Another reason is that for each research group or individual researchers who are not already familiar with the SP concepts, a significant amount of time and effort is likely to be required to get up to speed, so it is important to minimize other obstacles to make progress. For these reasons: • The process of registering with the system and gaining access to it should be as simple and straightforward as possible. • User-friendly. For all aspects and parts of the system, there should be a user-friendly interface.

sections.heading: 3.6 Open source
sections.text: As already mentioned, SPM should be open source. Specifically, anyone - even people who are not registered users of SPM - should be able to view the source code and documentation of each completed version of SPM and run each completed version. In accordance with these points, all versions of SPM should be "free software" under the GNU General Public License, described at www.gnu.org / licenses / gpl.html. In short, this means that every user should have: • The freedom to use the software for any purpose; • The freedom to customize the software to suit his needs; • The freedom to share the software with friends and neighbors; and • The freedom to share the changes that each user makes. This policy is consistent with and supports the long-established principle that science works best when ideas, observations and experimental results are freely available to everyone, without limitations.

sections.heading: 4 Costs
sections.text: The costs associated with SPF are estimated in the following sections: A table summarizing all estimated costs with totals is shown in Section 4.3.

sections.heading: 4.1 Development costs
sections.text: We estimate that three employees with the right skills who are already familiar with the host engine would be able to develop an SPF within two years. We suggest that it would be appropriate to hire a relatively high-level person, perhaps at a salary of around £60,000, another junior person, perhaps at a salary of around £40,000, and a third person, possibly a student, at a salary of around £20,000. We have assumed that the cost of employing a person is twice as high as the cost of their salary, and of course salaries would be paid for two years. We have allocated £15,000 for PCs, printers, software and similar facilities for the three employees. Given the importance of the site to SPF and the specialist skills required for good website design - including the skills needed to ensure that the site is "mobile friendly" - we believe that it would be reasonable to employ a web design company to set the framework for the site and advise on how it should be developed.

sections.heading: 4.2 Recurrent costs
sections.text: The annual cost of operating the SPF is estimated in the following sections and summarized in Section 4.3.

sections.heading: 4.2.1 Maintenance costs
sections.text: We believe that when the SPF is running, it needs support: to make sure it is running smoothly and to deal with problems that arise; to answer users "questions; to fix bugs in the system; and to refine the system in the light of user feedback. We believe that these things can be done by a person on a salary of about £40,000 per person, with an assistant for about £20,000 per person.

sections.heading: 4.2.2 Running costs
sections.text: As mentioned in Section 3.5, we believe that much of the research on SPF would place small demands on the host's computer and that the associated costs would probably be less than the cost of administering a fee system. Nevertheless, such costs must be covered; we estimate that they would amount to £10,000 per person.

sections.heading: 4.2.3 Awareness-raising costs
sections.text: In accordance with "Impact" policies of the UK Government and UK Research Councils (Section 2.9), it is important that SPF and what it can do should be known around the world, among academic and industrial researchers, among research administrators and policy makers, and among members of the general public. This can be achieved through the following main routes, each with associated costs: • Via essays in scientific journals and conference proceedings. Most of them would be prepared by research groups and individual researchers who use SPF £, and they would pay the associated costs. • In addition, there would be academic essays on SPF and SPM, prepared by the two authors of this proposal and staff who were recruited to develop SPF. The main costs here would be the cost of attending conferences and fees for open access publication. • The applicants and perhaps development staff as well as the papers on SPF and SPM, the papers on SPF and the specialist concepts that are recruited to develop SPF. The main costs here would be the cost of attending conferences and fees for open access publication. • The applicants and perhaps development staff as well as the papers on SPF and SPM, the papers on SPF and the technical staff that are available online, and the papers on SPF concepts could be related to the conferences of SPF, or the conferences there.

sections.heading: 4.2.4 Contingencies
sections.text: As with one-off development costs, we have set aside 10% for contingencies.

sections.heading: 4.3 Summary of costs
sections.text: In this section, Table 1 summarises our estimates of one-off costs for SPF (a total of £546,700) and recurring costs (a total of £151,800).

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: The broad scope of SP theory and the wide range of its potential benefits and applications mean that there are many more pathways that need to be explored than can be tackled by a single research group. By providing funding for researchers worldwide to participate and collaborate, the research institution proposed in this document would facilitate the further development of the SP system and the realisation of its potential. Given this potential and the relatively low cost of the proposed facility, the creation of this facility would be a good investment.

sections.heading: A Outline of the SP theory and SP computer
sections.text: Model SP theory is conceived as an abstract brain-like system that, from an "input" perspective, can receive new information about its senses and partially or completely compress it to generate old information, as schematically shown in Figure 2. In theory, information compression is the mechanism for learning and organizing knowledge as well as pattern recognition, reasoning, problem solving and much more. The following subsections outline the most important elements of SP theory and SP machine.

sections.heading: A.1 The SP computer model and the SP machine
sections.text: The SP theory is realized in the form of a computer model, SP71, which can be considered a version of the SP machine. As mentioned in the introduction, the use of a computer model as a vehicle for the theory has helped to reduce the ambiguity in the theory, it has provided a means of testing candidate ideas, many of which were rejected, and it is a means of demonstrating what can be done with the system. A sketch of the functioning of the SP computer model can be found in [19, Section 3.9], with more details, including pseudo code, in [19, Sections 3.10 and 9.2]. 28 Fully perfected source code for the SP71 computer model can be downloaded from a link at the bottom of www.cognitionresearch.org / sp.htm, and from "Framework files" at www.arxiv.org / abs / 1306.388.As mentioned above, we assume that the SP computer model will be the basis for creating the upload parallel SP71 source machine.

sections.heading: A.6 SP-neural
sections.text: Part of the SP theory is the idea most fully described in [19, Chapter 11] that the abstract concepts of symbols and patterns in SP theory can be realized more specifically in the brain with the accumulations of neurons in the cerebral cortex. The neural equivalent of an SP pattern is called pattern composition; the word "assembly" is used in this term because the concept of one structure to another is quite similar to that described and discussed in [19, Section 11.4.1]. The main difference is that the concept of pattern composition clearly consists in achieving the structure between two or more pattern compositions.

sections.heading: C Some potential benefits and applications of
sections.text: The SP SystemWith the SP System, there is a wide range of potential benefits and applications, some of which are outlined in the following sections. Some potential applications can be developed within relatively short periods of time using existing supercomputers or even ordinary computers, including the SP System as an intelligent database (Appendix C.6) and applications in areas such as medical diagnostics (Appendix C.13.3), pattern recognition (Appendix C.5), information compression (Appendix C.13.5), high-cost information transmission (Appendix C.13.1, [24, Section VIII]), bioinformatics (Appendix C.13.4) and natural language processing (Appendix C.4.3). More radical solutions, which may take longer to develop, include a radically new architecture for computers (Appendix C.2) and the development of the full potential of computer vision (Appendix C.7) and natural language processing (Appendix C.4) systems.

sections.heading: C.1 Simplification and integration of concepts
sections.text: Although some people may argue otherwise, the computer world suffers from a deep malaise: its fragmentation into innumerable concepts, schematically depicted in Figure 5, a myriad of different formalities and formats for presenting knowledge, each with its own way of processing [24, Section III], and the extraordinary complexity of many computer systems, especially software. The quest for simplification and integration in SP theory is in line with Occam's Razor, one of the most widely recognized principles of science. With respect to this principle, there is potential for a very considerable simplification of computer systems, combining hardware and software [26, Section 5] and for a seamless integration of different structures and functions [26, Sections 2 and 7].

sections.heading: C.2 A radically new architecture for computers
sections.text: The SP system has the potential to lay the groundwork for a radically new architecture for computers, either through the abstract model (with a central role for multi-alignment) or, more likely, through SP-Neural. Potential benefits of this new architecture would be human versatility and adaptability in the computing field, a significant simplification of the software and drastic reductions in the energy consumption of computers as well as their size and weight [24, Section IX].

sections.heading: C.3 Unsupervised learning
sections.text: SP theory stems in part from an earlier research program on grammatical conclusions and unsupervised learning of natural language, with minimum length coding as the central principle [16], [23, Section V-A3]. However, achieving the goals of SP research program entailed a radical reorganization of computer models with the development of multiple alignments as a framework for simplifying and integrating different structures and functions [23, Section V-A4]. The new model demonstrates skills in grammatical conclusion ([19, Chapter 9], Appendix A.3.3) and appears to have considerable potential for the further development of linguistic, visual and other knowledge.

sections.heading: C.4 Natural language processing
sections.text: In addition to the learning of linguistic knowledge (Appendix C.3), the SP system has strengths in the analysis of natural language, the production of natural language and the integration of syntactic and semantic knowledge as outlined in this section. These aspects of the system are described comprehensively in [21, Section 8] and in [19, Chapter 5]. C.4.1 The analysis of natural language shows how the syntactic dependence between the pluralistic subject of the sentence ("Np") and the pluralistic main verb ("Vp") can be expressed in words (lines 1 to 8).

sections.heading: C.8 Reasoning
sections.text: As fully described in [19, chapters 7 and 10, section 6.4] and more selectively in [21, section 10], the SP system is suitable for several types of argument: • One-step "deductive" thinking. • Abductive thinking. • Arguing with probable decision networks and decision trees. • Arguing with "rules." • Non-monotonous thinking and arguing with default values. • Arguing in Bayesian networks, including "clearing the way." • Causal diagnosis. • Arguing that is not supported by evidence. • Inheriting attributes in an object-oriented class hierarchy or heterarchy. There is also potential for spatial thinking [23, section IV-F1] and what-if arguing [23, section IV-F2]. These different types of arguments can work seamlessly without embarrassing incompatibilities and also for how they can be integrated seamlessly.

sections.heading: C.9 Planning and problem solving
sections.text: With data on flights between different cities represented by SP patterns, the SP computer model can find a route between any two cities (if there is such a route) and, if there are alternative routes, also find a route between two cities [19, Section 8.2]. If translated in text form, the SP computer model can solve geometric analogy problems as found in puzzle books and some IQ tests [19, Section 8.3], [21, Section 12].

sections.heading: C.10 Software engineering
sections.text: Although it may not seem obvious at first glance, the Multiple Alignment Framework can model several devices used in ordinary process programming, including: method, function, or subroutine; variable, value, and type; function with parameters; conditional statement; and means of repeating operations such as repetition... until or do... while [26, Section 6.6.1]. In accordance with best practice in software engineering, the SP system facilitates the integration of "programs" with "data." And, as already mentioned (Appendix A.4), the SP system supports object-oriented concepts such as class hierarchies with inheritance of attributes. In [26, Section 6.6.3] it is suggested that, since SP patterns are independent at the "top" level, they can be used to model parallel processes. Now it seems to be a better option to model parallel processes as parallel information streams, which are described in Appendix 2C-D patterns like SP].

sections.heading: C.11 Mathematics
sections.text: Aspects of mathematics can be understood in terms of some basic techniques of information compression: chunking-with-codes, schema-plus-correction and runlength coding [25], and some features of mathematics can be modelled in the SP system [19, chapter 10]. On the basis of this evidence and some other considerations, there is reason to believe that all mathematics can be understood in terms of information compression. There appear to be considerable implications for mathematics as well as for science - due to the importance of mathematics as the language of science. C.12 Human perception and cognition and neuroscience were part of the inspiration for SP theory in previous research on the role of information compression in the functioning of brains and nervous systems [1, 2, 3] and a research programme on learning a first language and language [16].

sections.heading: C.13.1 Big data
sections.text: The SP system can help solve nine problems related to big data [24]. In short, these problems and their potential solutions are: • Overcoming the problem of diversity in big data. Harmonizing different types of knowledge, different formats of knowledge and their diverse processing modes through a universal framework for the presentation and processing of knowledge (UFC). • Learning and discovery. Unattended learning or the discovery of "natural" structures in data. • Interpretation of data. The system has strengths in areas such as pattern recognition, information gathering, analysis and production of natural language, translation from one representation to another, different types of reasoning, planning and problem solving. • Speed: Analysis of data flows. The SP system lends itself to an incremental style by assimilating information as it is received, much like humans do.

sections.heading: C.13.2 Autonomous robots
sections.text: The SP system can help in the development of autonomous robots, i.e. robots that are not dependent on external intelligence or power supply, are mobile and display as much human intelligence as possible [23]. The three main areas in which it can contribute - problems with the efficiency and bulkiness of computers; the development of human versatility in robots and the development of human adaptability in robots - are summarised in Section 2.4.

sections.heading: C.13.3 Medical diagnosis
sections.text: The way in which the SP system can be used in medical diagnosis is described in [18]. Expected benefits of the SP system in this field of application include: • A format for presenting diseases that is simple and intuitive. • The ability to manage errors and uncertainties in diagnostic information. • The simplicity of storing statistical information as the incidence of diseases. • The system provides a method for evaluating alternative diagnostic hypotheses that yields true probabilities. • It is a framework that should facilitate the unattended learning of medical knowledge and the integration of medical diagnoses with other AI applications. The emphasis in [18] is on medical diagnosis as pattern recognition. But the SP system can also be applied to causal diagnosis [19, Section 7.9], [21, Section 10.5] so that it may be possible, for example, to establish that "patient fatigue is caused by anaemia that may be caused by a deficiency in the diet."

sections.heading: C.13.4 Bioinformatics
sections.text: Due to the central importance of multi-alignment in the SP system and the importance of this concept in bioinformatics, there is a clear potential for the SP system to find applications in this area [26, Section 6.10.2]. Multi-alignment, as developed in the SP system, has potential advantages over multi-alignment, as developed for bioinformatics. Another potential advantage of the SP system is its ability and potential for uncontrolled learning (appendices A.3.3 and C.3, and sources referred to there): • They have the potential to detect recurring patterns of any size within DNA sequences, amino acid sequences and the like - including discontinuous sequences jumping over intervening structures. • They have the potential to detect disjunctive classes of units with the context in which they are embedded. • With the right kind of data, there is the potential to discover structures and associations within and between DNA, proteins, enzymes and associated processes, and to believe that there is a biochemical basis in the systems.

metadata.abstractText: This is a proposal to create a research facility for the development of a high-parallel version of the SP machine, based on the SP theory of intelligence. We envisage that the new version of the SP machine will be an open-source software virtual machine, derived from the existing SP computer model, and hosted on an existing high-performance computer. It is intended as a means for researchers everywhere to explore what can be done with the system and to create new versions of it. The SP system is a unique attempt to simplify and integrate observations and concepts across artificial intelligence, mainstream computing, mathematics, and human perception and cognition, with information compression via the matching and unification of patterns as a unifying theme. Many potential benefits and applications flow from this simplification and integration. These include potential with problems associated with big data; potential to facilitate the development of autonomous robots; and potential in other areas including: unsupervised learning, natural language processing, several kinds of reasoning, fuzzy pattern recognition and recognition at multiple levels of abstraction, computer vision, best-match and semantic forms of information retrieval, software engineering, medical diagnosis, simplification of computing systems, and the seamless integration of diverse kinds of knowledge and diverse aspects of intelligence. The main elements of the proposed facility are described, including support for the development of SP-neural, a neural version of the SP machine. The facility should be permanent in the sense that it should be available for the foreseeable future, and it should be designed to facilitate its use by researchers anywhere in the world.
